nodes.title: Article 10
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines regulations for licensed diamond and gemstone buying/selling offices in Kinshasa and mining areas. It covers the one-year renewable validity of the license, the renewal criteria based on performance and tax payment, and the authorization for these offices to establish buying bureaus and hire staff. It also specifies that foreign individuals working in these bureaus must possess a mining sector work permit.

nodes.title: Article 13
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines the penalties for underperformance by an authorized precious mineral purchasing office. The main points are the specific financial and administrative sanctions applied at two intervals: a quarterly fine of 3.5% on the performance shortfall, and at the end of the fiscal year, the loss of the security deposit and non-renewal of the authorization. It also details the procedure for enforcing the fine.

nodes.title: Article 14
nodes.summary: The partial document outlines obligations and regulations for diamond and precious gemstone trading offices in Congo. Key points include mandatory monthly activity reports to mining authorities, disclosure of management details, daily purchase oversight, and specific procedures for sorting and sealing purchased diamond parcels. Non-compliance with reporting requirements results in a financial penalty.

nodes.title: Article 3
nodes.summary: This partial document defines the conditions under which Congolese nationals, specifically those holding an artisanal miner or trader card, are authorized to possess and transport diamonds and other precious/semi-precious stones within the national territory. The authorization applies everywhere except within areas covered by exclusive mining titles. It then clarifies that "exclusive mining titles" refer to specific permits and concessions issued for the exploration or exploitation of these stones.

nodes.title: Article 4
nodes.summary:
This partial document, Article 4, defines the legal status and operating rules for artisanal miners (exploitants artisanaux or creuseurs) in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It covers two main categories: diamond miners and miners of other precious/semi-precious stones.

The main points are:
1.  **Definition:** An artisanal miner is a Congolese national physically working in designated artisanal mining zones.
2.  **Sales Rights:** Miners are authorized to sell their extracted minerals to licensed buyers (négociants).
3.  **Operation on Licensed Concessions:** If mining occurs within an area covered by an exclusive mining title, it is only permitted with the agreement and supervision of the titleholder, who has the right of first refusal to purchase the minerals. Without this agreement, such artisanal mining is prohibited.
4.  **Export Prohibition:** Artisanal miners are strictly forbidden from directly exporting diamonds or other precious/semi-precious stones.

nodes.title: Article 5
nodes.summary: This partial document defines the legal status and obligations of diamond and precious/semi-precious stone dealers in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It specifies that a dealer must be a Congolese national who buys stones from artisanal mining sites and sells them to authorized trading houses. The document also mandates that dealers submit monthly sales statistics with supporting invoices to the local Mining Service. It outlines penalties for non-compliance, including a fine for failing to submit statistics and potential judicial prosecution for non-payment of the fine.

nodes.title: Article 6
nodes.summary: This partial document, Article 6, outlines the conditions for obtaining and renewing an artisanal miner's or dealer's card. It specifies separate requirements for each: the miner must provide proof of local civil registration, two passport photos, and payment of a fee to the Public Treasury. The dealer must provide a recent criminal record extract, an ID card, two passport photos, and the same fee proof. It also states that the validity of both cards is for one calendar year and can be renewed multiple times based on sufficient activity as judged by the Mines Department.

nodes.title: Article 9
nodes.summary:
This partial document outlines the application requirements and procedures for obtaining an "Agrément" (approval/license) to operate as a "Comptoir d'achat des pierres précieuses ou semi-précieuses" (a purchasing office for precious or semi-precious stones) in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

The main points covered are:
1.  **Application Submission:** The application must be submitted in duplicate to the Minister of Mines and filed with the Directorate of the Mining Service.
2.  **Required Documents for Individuals (Physical Persons):** A list of required documents is provided, including identification, photos, commercial registry copy, tax certificate, financial references, a security deposit proof, advance payment of the annual fee, and a criminal record extract.
3.  **Required Documents for Legal Entities (Moral Persons):** A separate list of required documents is provided, including commercial registry, notarized statutes, national ID number, tax certificate, security deposit proof, advance annual fee payment, and bank references detailing partners' capacities.
4.  **Administrative Processing:** The Directorate of the Mining Service acknowledges receipt, registers the application, processes it, checks for formal compliance, requests corrections or additions as needed, and initiates any necessary investigations.
